critique: This document pertains to the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 and outlines procedures for international cooperation regarding atomic energy. It delegates authority to the Secretary of Defense and the Atomic Energy Commission to make determinations on proposed cooperation and transfer arrangements, subject to certain conditions. It also clarifies the roles of the President and the Secretary of State in these matters. There is nothing explicitly ideological in the document. Immigration is not relevant. The document delegates some authority, but also retains some for the president, so it is neutral. Federalism is not relevant. The document focuses on national security. Economic regulation is not relevant. Social inclusion is not relevant.
